awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal will inaugurate a CyberCorps®: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at the New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) under the name Secure Computing Initiative (SCI). It proposes a novel cyber-security education model that combines four main features: (1) flexible cyber-security curricula; (2) experiential learning; (3) research-based learning; and (4) multi-tier mentoring. This model requires the funded students to participate in both in-class and out-of-class learning activities. In addition, it interleaves strong theoretical knowledge acquired in traditional courses with hands-on practical skills acquired in project-based courses. As part of the NJIT?s Cybersecurity Research Center, the project will establish an SFS lab to enable research-based learning. A team of PhD students, supported by the college, will mentor the SFS-funded MS and BS students. As part of the mentoring process, students will get an advice from the Security Clearance Advisory Board composed of NJIT administrative staff members who went through the clearance process during their previous careers. The board members will help the students understand the clearance process and also assist them when they are going through the process. The project team will work with NJIT?s Career Development Services (CDS) to achieve 100% placement for the SFS students. CDS has nurtured and maintained a long term relationship with governmental agencies and achieved high rates of placement for permanent positions as well as internships and coop opportunities.

The SCI program is designed to fulfill the national needs for cyber-security experts, to enhance discovery while promoting learning, and to increase the participation of women and under-represented groups in cybersecurity. SCI will also produce scientific results and publicly available software that will help the nation better protect against new cyber threats. Many of the proposed activities involve contact with the general public, and are prone to sensitize the society to the importance of cybersecurity. The outreach activities also include an enrichment program for high school students that focuses on cybersecurity education.

inst.inst_street_address: 323 DR MARTIN LUTHER KING JR BLVD

por.por_cntn:
The Secure Computing Initiative (SCI) at New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) was awarded in December 2015. The overarching goal of the program is to recruit students, train them, and place them with federal/state/local agencies in cybersecurity positions. Towards that goal, the program funded a mix of BS and MS students, seeking to graduate students with MS degrees in one of two cybersecurity programs (namely, MS in Cybersecurity and Privacy and MS in IT Administration and Security) offered at the Ying Wu College of Computing.

Intellectual Merit

The success of the program is due in large part to the quality of the MS programs we have at NJIT, the careful selection of the students, the mentorship system we put in place where each student in the program is assigned to one of the PIs, the involvement of the four research-active project investigators, and the extra-curricular activities built in the program. In addition to their participation in academics and research, the SCI scholars are required to get involved in extra-curricular activities such as:

  • TechWatch presentations.  Every semester, students in the program are required to form teams of two or three to give a 45-minute presentation on recent cybersecurity incidents popularized in the media. The presentations give an overview of the attack, describe the perpetrator of the attack and their motivation, as well as technical details of the attack such as the vulnerability that was exploited, the security properties that were violated, how the targeted organization discovered the attack, and what preventative or mitigation measures they took subsequently.
  • Soft-Skills training.  The soft skills training involves workshops and seminars with well-known guest speakers every semester. We have launched the ?soft-skills? training initiative with a two-hour, highly interactive Zoom leadership workshop for the SCI student cohort facilitated by Juliet Chin Hart, founder of Hart and Chin Associates, LLC, a New Jersey-based firm that specializes in training scientists and engineering to develop their interpersonal skills and leadership capabilities. Post-event formative assessment (via Survey Monkey) indicated that the students enjoyed the workshop and thought it was valuable. Based on this positive feedback, Chin-Hart was hired to offer a three-part workshop series (?Leading in a Diverse Environment?) in the Fall of 2022.
  • Cybersecurity Competitions.  Students enrolled in the program participate in several cyber competitions every year, including the CAE Regional Hackaton, the Governor's Cybersecurity Talent Competition, DamCTF, and WPICTF;  in addition, they also organize and run the popular JerseyCTF competition at NJIT.
    • JerseyCTF: JerseyCTF is a beginner-friendly Capture the Flag competition that aims to inspire interest in cybersecurity. JerseyCTF is hosted by the NJIT ACM student chapter and the SCI program. It is geared towards students and professionals alike. JerseyCTF provides participants with jeopardy-style questions in categories including cryptography, forensics, binary exploitation/reversing, open-source intelligence, and web exploitation.  It also features a parallel track to the CTF competition, consisting of presentations and panels with renowned speakers from industry and government. Starting in 2023, a SFS Cybercops track was added to allow teams from SFS Cybercops programs nationwide to compete and learn.

 

 

Broader Impact

The program has attracted a diverse pool of students from Fall 2016 to Fall 2020. Out of 33 students recruited, 9 (27%) are African Americans, 8 (24%) are females, 2 Hispanics (6%), 1 veteran (3%) and 1 transgender (3). Overall, 7 students (21%) were recruited from outside NJIT.

The program has achieved 100% internship placement every year and 100% job placement. All the 33 students recruited in the program have now graduated and are working: 24 (73%) are working for the executive branch of the federal government and 9 (27%) in federal non-executive branch or state agencies.

 


Last Modified: 07/10/2023
Modified by: Vincent Oria

The overarching goal of the program is to recruit students, train them, and place them with federal/state/local agencies in cybersecurity positions. In addition to their participation in academics and research, the SCI scholars are required to get involved in extra-curricular activities such as:

TechWatch presentations.  Every semester, students in the program are required to form teams of two or three to give a 45-minute presentation on recent cybersecurity incidents popularized in the media. The presentations give an overview of the attack, describe the perpetrator of the attack and their motivation, as well as technical details of the attack such as the vulnerability that was exploited, the security properties that were violated, how the targeted organization discovered the attack, and what preventative or mitigation measures they took subsequently.
Soft-Skills training.  The soft skills training involves workshops and seminars with well-known guest speakers every semester. We have launched the ?soft-skills? training initiative with a two-hour, highly interactive Zoom leadership workshop for the SCI student cohort facilitated by Juliet Chin Hart, founder of Hart and Chin Associates, LLC, a New Jersey-based firm that specializes in training scientists and engineering to develop their interpersonal skills and leadership capabilities. Based on this positive feedback, Chin-Hart was hired to offer a three-part workshop series (?Leading in a Diverse Environment?) in the Fall of 2022.
Cybersecurity Competitions.  Students enrolled in the program participate in several cyber competitions every year, including the CAE Regional Hackaton, the Governor's Cybersecurity Talent Competition, DamCTF, and WPICTF;  in addition, they also organize and run the popular JerseyCTF competition at NJIT. 

JerseyCTF: JerseyCTF is a beginner-friendly Capture the Flag competition that aims to inspire interest in cybersecurity. JerseyCTF is hosted by the NJIT ACM student chapter and the SCI program. It is geared towards students and professionals alike. JerseyCTF provides participants with jeopardy-style questions in categories including cryptography, forensics, binary exploitation/reversing, open-source intelligence, and web exploitation.  It also features a parallel track to the CTF competition, consisting of presentations and panels with renowned speakers from industry and government. Starting in 2023, a SFS Cybercops track was added to allow teams from SFS Cybercops programs nationwide to compete and learn.




 

 

Broader Impact

The program has attracted a diverse pool of students from Fall 2016 to Fall 2020. Out of 33 students recruited, 9 (27%) are African Americans, 8 (24%) are females, 2 Hispanics (6%), 1 veteran (3%) and 1 transgender (3). Overall, 7 students (21%) were recruited from outside NJIT.

The program has achieved 100% internship placement every year and 100% job placement. All the 33 students recruited in the program have now graduated and are working: 24 (73%) are working for the executive branch of the federal government and 9 (27%) in federal non-executive branch or state agencies.
